ElementDescription: The NDAR Global Unique Identifier (GUID) for research subject
Subject ID how it's defined in lab/project
Date on which the interview/genetic test/sampling/imaging/biospecimen was completed. MM/DD/YYYY
Age in months at the time of the interview/test/sampling/imaging.
Notes: Age is rounded to chronological month. If the research participant is 15-days-old at time of interview, the appropriate value would be 0 months. If the participant is 16-days-old, the value would be 1 month.

ElementDescription: Sex of subject at birth
Notes: M = Male; F = Female; O=Other; NR = Not reported

ElementDescription: Thought that he/she might stop breathing
Thought about the infant being smothered
Thought that the infant could suffocate while sleeping
Thought that the infant could die of SIDS (Sudden Infant Death Syndrome)
Thought of hitting the infant too hard when burping him/her
Unwanted thoughts of screaming, shaking, or slapping the infant
Thoughts of purposely drowning the baby
Thoughts of stabbing the infant
Thoughts of burning the infant with hot water
Thoughts about mistakenly puncturing the baby's soft spot
Thoughts about the baby dying because of an accident
Fears of dropping the infant while holding him/her
Thoughts of dropping the infant from a high place
Fears that the infant will be injured if picked up wrong
Fears that the infant will choke on something (e.g., toy, food)
Thoughts that an animal (i.e., a dog) might attack baby
Thoughts about the baby drowning during a bath
Thoughts about a car accident involving the infant
Thoughts of something happening to you (or spouse/partner) and you  can't care for the baby
Fear that you will forget the infant in the car seat
Unwanted thoughts that you could give the infant away
Fear that someone might take the infant
Unwanted thoughts about leaving the baby somewhere when he/she is crying
Thought about the baby getting sick from the floor or unclean surfaces
Thoughts about the baby getting sick from bodily waste
Concerns about household items (cleansers/solvents/bleaches)
Concerns about animals or insects coming into contact with the baby
Concerns that you or someone else will somehow contaminate the baby
Unacceptable thoughts about the baby's genitals
Thoughts about the baby's sexuality or future sexual orientation
Unacceptable sexual thoughts during breastfeeding (females only)
Other senseless and unwanted sexual thoughts about the baby
Unrealistic fears that the baby has a serious medical illness or disease (cerebral palsy, MS, developmental disability)

How much of your time is occupied by the senseless, unwanted thoughts about your new baby? How frequently do these thoughts or ideas occur? (Consider both the number of times and the duration of the thoughts)
Notes: 0=None; 1=Mild, less than 1 hour/day or occasional thoughts; 2=Moderate, 1-3 hours/day or frequent thoughts; 3=Severe, 3-8 hours/day or very frequent thoughts; 4=Extreme, greater than 8 hours/day or near constant thoughts

ElementDescription: How much do these thoughts interfere with your family, social or work (or other role) functioning? Are there things you can't do because of the thoughts?
Notes: 0=None; 1=Mild, slight interference, but overall performance not impaired; 2=Moderate, definite interference, but still manageable; 3=Severe, causes substantial impairment in performance; 4=Extreme, incapacitating

ElementDescription: How much distress do these senseless and unwanted thoughts cause you?
Notes: 0=None; 1=Mild, not too  disturbing; 2=Moderate, disturbing but still manageable; 3=Severe, very disturbing; 4=Extreme, near constant disabling distress

ElementDescription: How much of an effort do you make to resist these thoughts? How often do you try to turn your attention away, or disregard them? (Rate only your effort to resist, not success or failure)
Notes: 0=I always make an effort to resist, or I don't need to make an effort; 1=I try to resist most of the time; 2=I make some effort to resist; 3=I yield to the thoughts without attempting to resist, but with reluctance; 4=I completely and willingly yield to all of the thoughts

ElementDescription: How much control do you  have over the thoughts? How successful are you  at stopping or diverting them when they occur? Can you dismiss them?
Notes: 0=I have complete control over the thoughts; 1=Much control, I am usually able to stop or divert the thoughts; 2=Moderate control, I am sometimes able to stop or divert the thoughts; 3=Little control, I'm rarely successful in stopping or dismissing the thoughts; 4=No control, I am unable to even temporarily alter them

ElementDescription: Give yourself reassurance that things are OK?
Spend time trying to rationalize or make sense of the thought?
Check on the baby more frequently?
Distract yourself from other activities?
Distract yourself from other thoughts?
Try to suppress or stop the unwanted intrusive thoughts as quickly as possible?
Avoid situations in which the thought comes up?
Examples of situations avoided
Avoid your infant?
Get social support (such as talking to your spouse or parent)?
Ask other people if the thoughts are "OK" or "normal"?
Confess to others that you've had the thoughts?
Pray about the thoughts?
Other strategies used to respond to the thoughts?
How much time do you spend engaged in the strategies? How often do you used them in response to unwanted thoughts? (Consider both the number of times and how much time you  spend)
Notes: 0=None; 1=Mild, less than 1 hour/day or occasional performance; 2=Moderate, 1-3 hours/day or frequent performance; 3=Severe, 3-8 hours/day or very frequent performance; 4=Extreme, greater than 8 hours/day or near constant performance

ElementDescription: How much do these strategies interfere with your family, social or work (or other role) functioning? Are there things you can't do because of the strategies?
Notes: 0=None; 1=Mild, slight interference, but overall performance not impaired; 2=Moderate, definite interference, but still manageable; 3=Severe, causes substantial impairment in performance; 4=Extreme, incapacitating

ElementDescription: How would you feel if you were prevented from performing these strategies when you felt as if you needed to perform them? That is, how anxious/worried would you  become?
Notes: 0=None; 1=Mild, not too  disturbing; 2=Moderate, disturbing but still manageable; 3=Severe, very disturbing; 4=Extreme, near constant disabling distress

ElementDescription: How much of an effort do you make to resist performing these strategies?
Notes: 0=Always make an effort to resist, or doesn't need to make an effort; 1=Tries to resist most of the time; 2= Makes some effort to resist; 3=Yields to fears without attempting to resist, but with reluctance; 4= Completely and willingly yields to all fears

ElementDescription: How strong is the drive to perform these strategies when an unwanted thought comes to mind?
Notes: 0=Complete control; 1=Much control, usually able to stop or divert behaviors; 2=Moderate control, sometimes able to stop or divert behaviors; 3=Little control, rarely successful in stopping or diverting behaviors; 4=No control, drive to perform behaviors is overpowering, rarely able to even delay performance
